sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Review

Preserving the Past

Every month, people worldwide upload about 6 billion photos to the Internet. Photography is now so common, it is easy to forget that photographs - and the memories they hold - can be very precious.

Memory Archive

In a cold, windowless basement in Washington D.C., there is a man who knows the real value of a photograph. Since 1983, Bill Bonner has looked after National Geographic’s photo archive. The archive holds around 8 million prints - many over 100 years old.

In his long career, Bonner has looked at hundreds of thousands of photos. He believes each image holds a memory. Some record moments in history; others show \"people like us, just doing our thing, living our life.\" Even when forgotten by the outside world, these pictures still tell us much about the past.

Images From the Past

When the archive’s earliest photos were taken, photography was difficult and expensive. Photographers needed special equipment and chemicals to develop pictures. Cameras were large and heavy - some weighed 20 pounds (9 kilos) or more. Early explorers used these massive cameras to photograph people and places most people had never seen.

Photography expeditions took months or even years. \"They dedicated their lives to this,\" Bonner says. Many images are fragile, and he feels responsible for preserving them for people now and in the future. For Bonner, these figures from the distant past are almost like ancestors. \"It’s like opening your grandparents’ family album for the first time.\"

1 archive: a place that stores historical materials

2 develop: to make a picture from film using special chemicals

3 ancestor: a relative who lived long ago

items.q: People around the world take about 6 billion photos every month.
Because photographs are so common today, people don't realize how important they can be.
All of the photos in the National Geographic Archive are over 100 years old.
The archive includes both historic photos and images of day-to-day life.
Early cameras were larger and heavier than today's cameras.
Early photography expeditions sometimes lasted for years.
Some of the photographs in the archive are of Bonner's actual ancestors.

sections.passage:
Remember This

There is a 41-year-old woman known as \"AJ,\" who remembers almost every day of her life since age 11. There is an 85-year-old man known as \"EP,\" who remembers only his most recent thought.

AJ remembers dates, events, weather, emotions — almost everything. Her ability is called hyperthymestic syndrome.

EP cannot make new memories. A virus in 1960 destroyed the medial temporal lobes in his brain, including the hippocampus. He remembers his childhood clearly, but nothing after 1960.

Alexander Luria, a Russian psychologist, once studied a man known as \"S\" who could remember almost everything. S could remember long lists of numbers and words with no difficulty. Another man, Kim Peek, could read two pages at the same time. Many people think Peek was the inspiration for the movie Rain Man.

AJ says she can remember each day of her life in great detail. If you say a date, she can tell you what day of the week it was, what she did, how she felt, and what the weather was like. \"She’s not easily stumped,\" the author writes. Scientists from the University of California have studied her for years. They have also studied EP to understand how memory works.

EP is like a digital camera without a working memory chip. He can see things, but he forgets them almost immediately. Scientists say that long-term memories are stored in the neocortex, which was not damaged by the virus. This is why EP can still remember his childhood.

items.q: The author mentions specific dates in paragraph 2 in order to...
options: point out some important events in AJ's life
show how good her memory is
indicate that she sometimes forgets things

items.q: Alexander Luria is a...
"She's not easily stumped" means AJ rarely...
AJ is different from Kim Peek and S because she can remember...
The author indicates that the scientists from the University of California...
options: have never studied someone like AJ
finally understand why AJ has such a memory

items.q: EP's memory problems were caused by...
Long-term memories are stored in...
Why does the author compare EP to a digital camera without a working memory chip?
options: he can remember images but not words
he can remember perfectly but can't speak
he sees things but forgets immediately

items.q: EP is most likely to remember...
options: what he had for breakfast this morning

sections.passage:
Selfie Statistics

An article in Time magazine listed the places where people take the most selfies. Makati City, in the Philippines, has about 1.5 million people and nearly 260 selfies per 100,000 persons.

Manhattan, in New York City, has just under 400,000 people. In Manhattan, people take approximately 200 selfies per 100,000 residents.

Worldwide selfie averages were not included in the report, but other sources say the global average is about average.

sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Match each question with the paragraph (A–E) where the answer is found.
sections.passage:
One Second Every Day

Paragraph A

One Second Every Day is a project where a person records one second of video every day and then edits all the clips together into a movie of their life.

Paragraph B

Cesar Kuriyama began the project because he once forgot something important. That moment made him want to create a way to remember his days. He says he will never forget again because he now records every day.

Paragraph C

If he lives to 80, his movie will be about 5 hours long, made of one-second clips from each day of his life.

Paragraph D

Sometimes it is difficult to choose the one second to record because many things can happen in a day. He uses memory and visualization to select the moment.

Paragraph E

He also records difficult or sad days. He once recorded moments related to a tragedy in his family because he believes all experiences matter.

items.q: Why did Cesar Kuriyama begin his project?
Why will he not forget again?
How long is each recording?
Why is it sometimes difficult to choose?
Why record bad experiences?
How old was he when he began?
What is his project?
How long will the movie be if he lives to 80?
